content.raw:
I added a small bit of refactoring in [branch line_scpeters](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign_math/commits/branch/line_scpeters):

* Colinear -> Collinear dc108a8
* small test modifications 10dc96a
* added a few extra degenerate line (zero length) test cases 49548f7

As of 49548f7, the test is failing. I think I set up the expectations properly for a consistent API, but that should be checked before trying to fix it.
content.html:
I added a small bit of refactoring in branch line_scpeters:

  • Colinear -> Collinear dc108a8
  • small test modifications 10dc96a
  • added a few extra degenerate line (zero length) test cases 49548f7

As of 49548f7, the test is failing. I think I set up the expectations properly for a consistent API, but that should be checked before trying to fix it.

content.raw:
I agree; I don't want to throw an error. I guess for the Parallel function, it could go either way and we should just document its behavior for degenerate cases.

For the Collinear function, though, it would be nice to give the same result when giving a point (Vector2d) or a degenerate line segment constructed from two instances of that same point. I'm working on an update to the test.
content.html:
I agree; I don't want to throw an error. I guess for the Parallel function, it could go either way and we should just document its behavior for degenerate cases.

For the Collinear function, though, it would be nice to give the same result when giving a point (Vector2d) or a degenerate line segment constructed from two instances of that same point. I'm working on an update to the test.

content.raw:
What do you think would be an appropriate method to handle this? We could

1) Return false if a line segment has zero length.

2) Return true because a point is parallel to everything.

3) Throw an error that one segment has zero length.

I'd prefer not to throw an error.
content.html:
What do you think would be an appropriate method to handle this? We could

1) Return false if a line segment has zero length.

2) Return true because a point is parallel to everything.

3) Throw an error that one segment has zero length.

I'd prefer not to throw an error.

content.html: Should this be \return instead of a second \brief? This happens a few places in this file.

content.html: There's still an issue with line segments of zero length. They will register as parallel to everything. Should I make an issue for this?

content.raw: I think this check would be overly strict. There could be use cases for such a scenario. Checking for equality in floating point number is also tricky. The constructor would have to take an epsilon value.
content.html: I think this check would be overly strict. There could be use cases for such a scenario. Checking for equality in floating point number is also tricky. The constructor would have to take an epsilon value.

content.html: Right. I've added a parallel function and an improved colinear function.

content.raw: This should be false. These lines are parallel but not collinear.
content.html: This should be false. These lines are parallel but not collinear.

content.raw:
The Colinear() functions currently check if the cross product of the line segment with a point or another line segment is zero. This will be true if one of the line segments has zero length.

Additionally, the Colinear(Line2) function will return true if the two line segments are parallel. Collinearity requires line segments to be parallel and intersecting.
content.html:
The Colinear() functions currently check if the cross product of the line segment with a point or another line segment is zero. This will be true if one of the line segments has zero length.

Additionally, the Colinear(Line2) function will return true if the two line segments are parallel. Collinearity requires line segments to be parallel and intersecting.

content.raw: Regarding instances of colinear or co-linear, the [dictionary says collinear](http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/collinear)
content.html: Regarding instances of colinear or co-linear, the dictionary says collinear

content.raw: It looks like this doesn't actually check whether the point is on the line segment. It constructs a 2D equivalent of an axis-aligned bounding box and verifies if the point is inside that bounding box. Am I reading it right?
content.html: It looks like this doesn't actually check whether the point is on the line segment. It constructs a 2D equivalent of an axis-aligned bounding box and verifies if the point is inside that bounding box. Am I reading it right?
